Investigations: Throat swab for rapid antigen detection test (RADT) for Group A Streptococcus
Justification: To rule out or confirm streptococcal pharyngitis, which is a common cause of sore throat and requires antibiotic treatment.
If the rapid antigen test is negative, a throat culture can be performed to confirm the presence of bacterial infection, especially if symptoms persist.
To check for signs of infection or inflammation, such as elevated white blood cell count, which can help differentiate between viral and bacterial causes.
To rule out infectious mononucleosis, especially given the fever and sore throat symptoms.
To assess the level of inflammation in the body, which can help in determining the severity of the infection.
